Ok, time for something petty that has always bothered me: why are planted flags considered "flights in progress"?

When you resume a saved game, it says " X flights in progress" under the name of the game where X is the number of ships, bases, rovers, probes, and stations you have in flight (basically, anything with a capsule or probe core). I find this weird, since a flag is not a controllable object (yes, you can focus on them, but you can't do anything with them). Why would it be included in the count with capsules and probes, but debris is not? Shouldn't debris be included then too?

My preference would be to not include planted flags in the "flights in progress" count. Like I said, its just a petty detail that bothers me.
Well they could be flights--haven't you ever run a flag over with a rover?

Actually I wouldn't. On the list of "things fixed in 1.0," if "Flags are now not considered flights in progress" was in the list, my personal hype-list would have it somewhere near "We fixed the spelling in this submenu that nobody ever noticed until late one night I saw red squiggly lines under the word in the config file."

I'm much happier that they've been working on pretty much every single other thing in the game, rather than this.

Except the whole ROUND-8 thing. Not too happy about that.

Because the flags are objects represented as separate Tracking Station entities. The game refers to these objects as "flights".

I mean, come on guys. What do you want them to do, make special categories for Objects That Do Not Fly?
On the same note, why are bases and rovers considered flights? Feels like they are better called missions.

Because the flags are objects represented as separate Tracking Station entities. The game refers to these objects as "flights".

Except it doesn't include debris, which are also represented in the Tracking Station. And since debris is hidden by default from the tracking station, as are flags, you'd think they'd treat them the same way for "flights in progress"

It's not about the semantic use of the word "flights" for things that aren't flying (I mean, you do fly a flag, afterall) but more about the fact that once a flag is up, you're never going to do anything with it again, so why act like it's some active thing? I like to keep my active flights from cluttering up by turning useless things into debris when I'm done with it. This way, when I load up a save and it says "10 flights in progress" that means there are 10 things I'm currently paying attention to/working on. I don't want it saying "50 flights in progress" because I planted a bunch of flags everywhere.

Why are flags considered "flights"?

Because programming. I would guess a "flight" actually means an "instance/item/object to track in game". As it's tracked and a thing, the game (programmers) puts it in the same space as "flights" and space craft.

also since debris is something that you can choose not to leave laying around (the slider in the options) they dont want you loosing flags because of that.

that being said, they can make it a pseudo debris that never gets cleaned up.
